DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the malignant neoplasm of an anatomic site targeted for a particular therapeutic intervention.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Exposure as Collected Domain Malignant Neoplasm Therapeutic Procedure Targeted Anatomic Site
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: This interventions domain model reflects protocol-specified study treatment administrations, as collected._A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process._An anatomic site targeted for a particular medical intervention.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: This interventions domain model reflects protocol-specified study treatment administrations, as collected.

Concepts.definition: This interventions domain model reflects protocol-specified study treatment administrations, as collected.

Property.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Therapeutic Procedure Targeted Anatomic Site
Property.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.:An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.:An anatomic site targeted for a particular medical intervention.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.
An anatomic site targeted for a particular medical intervention.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).
